answers.answer: Has your doctor checked you for pre-eclampsia yet?
I would also watch out on the high sodium products. Soda drinks, salt, pork, ham etc..
I would call your Dr or go into the hospital to labor and delivery and get checked out. your B/P coukd be high and the can check your urine for proteins.  Better safe then sorry

I agree I would go to the labor and delivery to get checked out and better safe then sorry. Do you have a handheld blood pressure cuff? I got one at Walmart I think they have some that are like $30. Everytime I swell my blood pressure goes up some! Has baby been moving like he/she has been before? I definitely would go have them check you out.

By week 14 my lower legs down to my toes began swelling (especially as the day progressed).  (Whereas many women begin to swell in late 2nd Trimester, my symptoms started fairly early.  Normal blood pressure & salt intake, no preeclampsia).Here are some tips that helped me the most:1)  I rested/slept with feet elevated on pillows above heart level.  This as well as...2)  Lying on my LEFT side to reduce compression of the uterus on major vessels of the right side of the body helped A LOT!For numbers 1) and 2) I bought the "All Nighter Total Body Pregnancy Pillow" by Leachco, which has improved swelling & sleep dramatically3)  Putting on compression hose before I get out of bed– so I don't give my legs time to swell– has helped the MOST.  (Speak to your doc, but mine recommended at least thigh-high 20-30 PSI hose).4)  Walk 20-30 min most days.5)*Temporary relief: Standing/walking in neck-high water is said to effectively force extra fluid from tissues back into the vessels.6)  Drink lots of water (2 liters) to reduce water retention7)  * If feet are really swollen by the evening, prop them up & apply ice pack  10-15 min

question: For the passed three days I've been swelling up from my legs down to my toes...I cant even wiggle my toes and my right foot hurts to touch....has this ever happened to anyone?or what should I do? Its never happened to me before.
title: really bad swelling
